  - You're presenting the Coaching Plan, client launches into a new concern

  How to redirect warmly:
  - "I love that you're thinking about this - and that's exactly the kind of thing we'll dive into in our next session. Let me just get us booked so we have time set aside to explore that fully. [Continue with booking]"
  - "That's a great question, and I want to give it the attention it deserves rather than rushing through it now. Let's lock in our next time first, and we'll tackle that right away when we meet. [Continue with booking]"
  - "I'm so glad that came up - I'm writing that down so we make sure to address it next time. First, let's get you scheduled so we have dedicated space for that conversation. [Continue with booking]"

  The key: Acknowledge, validate, promise to address it, redirect back to NBG. Don't ignore them, but don't get pulled off track either.

  Here's the retention reality: if you get derailed and never complete NBG, they likely won't book. You need to gently hold the boundary while maintaining warmth. This is good coaching AND good business - you're teaching them that sessions have structure, time boundaries matter, and you'll address their concerns properly in the next session rather than rushing through them at the end!


---

Step: General NBG
Sub-Step: Delivery
Mistake: Over-explaining/Rambling

  Gold Standard: Keep NBG clear, concise, and purposeful. Say what needs to be said, then pause. Don't fill every silence with unnecessary talking.

  What happened: You over-explained throughout NBG - giving too much information, too many options, or filling every pause with additional talking. This created confusion, overwhelm, and reduced conversion.

  Going forward: More words doesn't equal better results. In fact, over-explaining is one of the fastest ways to talk yourself out of a sale. Here's what happens when you ramble:
  - You create decision fatigue by providing too many options
  - You undermine your own confidence by over-justifying
  - You fill important silence that clients need to process and decide
  - You introduce doubts or objections they hadn't thought of yet
  - You make simple things sound complicated

  What over-explaining looks like:

  Future Work rambling: "So we'll work on boundaries, and I mean really understanding what boundaries are and how to communicate them effectively, and it's not just about saying no but about knowing what you need and being able to express that clearly without guilt, and we'll also look at why boundaries have been hard for you historically and what patterns might be underneath that..." [Client glazes over, loses the thread]

  Booking rambling: "Let's get you scheduled, I mean if you want to, and we can look at next week, or maybe the week after if that's better, and I have mornings and afternoons, though some days are more open than others, and we can always move it if your schedule changes, so there's no pressure..." [Creates hesitation through tentative over-explaining]

  Purchase rambling: "The 20-session package is great because it gives you time, and I think time is really important, not that you couldn't make progress with fewer sessions, but having more sessions means we don't have to rush, and you'll also save money per session, which is nice, and there's installments available, though you don't have to use those if you don't want to..." [Confuses value proposition, undermines confidence]

  What concise delivery looks like:

  Future Work concise: "We'll work on three things: establishing clear boundaries with Jake, rebuilding your communication confidence, and addressing that self-blame pattern. How does that sound?" [Clear, memorable, purposeful]

  Booking concise: "Let's get you in early next week so we can work on that message to him while everything's fresh. Which day works better - Tuesday or Wednesday?" [Direct, purposeful, moves forward]

  Purchase concise: "Based on the work we outlined, I recommend the 20-session package. Sessions are $120/hour compared to $180 single sessions. This package also includes installments if you'd prefer to split the payments. How does that sound?" [Clear value, simple decision]

  Remember these principles:
  - Say what needs to be said, then stop
  - Trust the pause - silence is okay
  - Don't fill gaps with nervous talking
  - One clear point > three confusing points
  - Less is often more in conversion conversations

  Be clear, be concise, be confident. Then pause and let your words land!


---

Step: General NBG
Sub-Step: Client Management
Mistake: Not Adapting to Resistance

  Gold Standard: Stay flexible and responsive when clients show hesitation. Adjust your approach based on their specific concerns rather than rigidly following a script.

  What happened: When the client expressed resistance or hesitation, you either ignored it and pushed forward with your script, or you gave up entirely. You didn't adapt your approach to address their specific concern.

  Going forward: NBG requires both structure AND flexibility. While you need to follow the three-step sequence, you also need to read the client and adapt when resistance appears.

  What resistance looks like:
  - Price concerns
  - Scheduling uncertainty
  - Hesitation about commitment
  - Questions about value
  - General reluctance

  Bad response #1 - Ignoring resistance: Client: "That's more than I expected to spend." Coach: [Continues with script] "Great, so I'll go ahead and process your card now." [Client feels unheard, resistance hardens]

  Bad response #2 - Giving up: Client: "That's more than I expected to spend." Coach: "Oh, okay. Well, think about it and let me know." [Lost sale, client likely never books]

  Good response - Adapting: Client: "That's more than I expected to spend." Coach: "I hear you on budget - that makes total sense. Let's find a way to make this work. I can offer you the 10-session package at a discounted rate, which brings it down to $X per session. How does that sound?" [Addresses concern, offers solution, keeps momentum]

  The key to adapting:
  - Acknowledge the concern (don't ignore or minimize it)
  - Understand the real issue (is it total price? timing? commitment level?)
  - Offer one specific solution that addresses their concern
  - Maintain forward momentum while being responsive

  Examples of adaptation:
  - Timing concern: "I'm not sure about my schedule next week" → Offer placeholder: "Let's pencil something in now and you can always adjust it"
  - Commitment concern: "I don't know if I need 20 sessions" → Adjust package: "Let's start with 10 sessions and see how it goes"
  - Value concern: "I'm not sure this will help" → Reinforce Future Work: "Remember, we're specifically working on [their urgent goals]"
  - Budget concern: "I can't afford this right now" → Offer alternatives: "I can do session-by-session at the package rate so there's no big upfront cost"

  Stay responsive, stay flexible, stay solution-oriented. The structure guides you, but adaptation closes the sale!


---

Step: General NBG
Sub-Step: Framing
Mistake: Treating NBG as Separate from Session

  Gold Standard: NBG is a seamless part of the coaching experience, not a separate "logistics" phase. It should feel like a natural continuation of the care and support you've provided.

  What happened: You framed or treated NBG as separate from the actual coaching - saying things like "Okay, now we're done with the real session, let's handle logistics" or shifting your entire demeanor to indicate "coaching time is over, business time begins."

  Going forward: This framing is one of the most damaging things you can do to conversion. When you treat NBG as separate, you're essentially telling the client:
  - The valuable part is over
  - This next part is just administrative
  - The coaching has ended and now we're doing something different
  - This is the "business" part you have to endure

  What separating sounds like:
  - "Okay, we're done with coaching - now let's talk logistics"
  - "The hard part is over, now we just need to handle booking"
  - "So that's the session - let me just quickly run through the packages"
  - "Now for the not-fun part..." [laughs nervously]

  What integration looks like:
  NBG is framed as caring for the client's continued growth, not as separate logistics:
  - Future Work: This is you as a coach outlining the thoughtful, personalized plan for their continued growth. It's an extension of your coaching wisdom.
  - Booking: This is you ensuring they have protected time and space to continue the important work you've started together. It's caring for their commitment.
  - Purchase: This is you helping them invest in their own growth and success. It's supporting their goals.

  The language shift:
  - Separate (weak): "Okay, coaching's done! Now let's handle the business stuff."
  - Integrated (strong): "So here's what our work together will look like going forward..." [Seamless transition]
  - Separate (weak): "Real quick, we just need to get you booked and handle payment."
  - Integrated (strong): "Let's make sure you have time on the calendar to continue this important work. I want to get you in next week so we can..." [Purpose-driven, connected to their goals]

  Here's the mindset shift: NBG isn't something separate you do TO clients - it's something you do FOR clients. You're extending care, offering continued support, and helping them commit to their own growth. When you see it that way and communicate it that way, clients feel it.

  The entire session - from opening small talk to final payment - is one cohesive experience of support and growth. Keep it integrated, keep it seamless, keep it focused on their success!
